name: MO 6
language: 2 Microsoft BASIC interpreters - MO5 compatible and BASIC 128
keyboard: Full stroke 69 key with 5 function keys and arrow keys
graphics: 8 modes, from 160 x 200 to 640 x 200 dots
ports: Light Pen, Joystick, Mouse, Centronics, Cartridge, External Audio, Bus, RGB
description:
The Thomson MO 6 was the successor of the Thomson MO 5. This machine was widely used in French schools. It was compatible with the MO 5 and the other members of its family (TO 7, TO 8, TO 9 and TO 9 plus).

It has two versions of BASIC on ROM, one to be compatible with MO5 and BASIC 128 (both made by Microsoft). Almost all memory (101 KB) was accessible with BASIC thanks to a transparent 16 KB bank switching mechanism. An optional 3.5" floppy disk drive (640 KB) was available.

It had a short life because soon after it was launched, the TO 8 came and challenged to it.

The MO5 was also sold in Italy by Olivetti under the name  Prodest PC-128

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color = "red">(1)</font> Two ROM chips holding two versions of Microsoft BASIC<br> <font color = "red">(2)</font> ROM cartridges connector<br> <font color = "red">(3)</font> TV aerial modulator<br> <font color = "red">(4)</font> I/O are managed by Two 6821P PIA chips <br> <font color = "red">(5)</font> EF-9369P graphics video chip<br> <font color = "red">(6)</font> Keyboard connectors<br> <font color = "red">(7)</font> Four 41464 (64 cells x 4 bits) chips hold 128 Kb of RAM<br> <font color = "red">(8)</font> Custom gate array chip made by Texas Instruments<br> <font color = "red">(9)</font> Motorola 6809EP processor<br> <font color = "red">(10)</font> Power supply unit<br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOX - REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>John V. Blankenbaker designed the Kenbak-1 and marketed in the pages of Scientific American in 1971. The machine's name was taken from the middle of John's last name.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.vintage-computer.com" target="_blank">www.vintage-computer.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Better features, cheaper price, the PC price war  has just started.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Teleplay advert for the Teleng Colourstars<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.geocities.com/doubledragon0uk//Home.html" target="_blank">Double  Dragon Retro Mess</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As the first advert campaing was not a good idea, NEC of America replaced it with this one... which was not better</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRIDGE COMPUTER VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>In 1982, the <b>Bridge Computer Company</b> (Newton, MASS) sold a Z80 software developper system with the InterSystems mainframe, CP/M 2.2 operating system and various optional  programming languages.The configuration was:<br><br> - 6 Mhz. Z80-B CPU with memory management<br> - 256 KB RAM expandable to 1 MB<br> - Two 8" or 5.25" F.D. drives, single or double sided<br> - Optional 5" or 8" hard disk, up to 40 MB<br> - Televideo serial video terminal. <br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Does this sound too good to be true? Just fill your tank with the BRIDGE 3C formula for SPEED and shift into 'overdrive' with your bridge 3C Compiler System. Leave the other behind, let us provide you with the fuel for higher productivity...</font>  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated september 1983 says : <br><br> "<b>Orchidée : the fabulous computer</b> (!)<br> With Orchidee, discover you can drive a formula 1 computer and never open the hood. Orchidee offers power and speed of a real professional computer with, as a gift, a lot of innovations never yet combined : interchangeable processors, including the fabulous IAPX 186, removable software cartridges, mouse, light pen. Whether you are a computer specialist or not, you have a fabulous professional tool."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Pravetz Apple II compatible technology and price  are compared with the IBM compatible Pravetz 8C.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b> for the English translation</p></blockquote>

item.description: 5.25'' disk drive|||320 KB model|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> 5.25'' DISK DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 320 KB model</strong><br><blockquote>This 5.25'' disk-drive offers a 320 KB capacity (40 tracks > 16 sectors > 256 bytes) and a built-in controller.</blockquote>

Disk Controller|||CD 90-351|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK CONTROLLER</strong></font><br><strong>> CD 90-351</strong><br><blockquote>This interface was used to connect a disk drive or a Quick Disc Drive (QDD) to a TO-7, TO-7/70, MO5 or MO6.</blockquote>
Joystick module||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> JOYSTICK MODULE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual Atari compatible joysticks module</blockquote>

Music & Game Module|||CM 90-112|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MUSIC & GAME MODULE</strong></font><br><strong>> CM 90-112</strong><br><blockquote>This module offers two joystick connectors (Videopac joysticks can be used) and adds three channels to the TO-7  or MO-5 (resulting in a total of 4 voices). Sadly, these new sound features were scarcely used in games...</blockquote>

Ordi 94|||Joystick Interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORDI 94</strong></font><br><strong>> Joystick Interface</strong><br><blockquote>This interface enables Atari joysticks to be used with TO-7, TO-7/70 and MO5. It was sold by Ordivisuel under the name Ordi 94.</blockquote>
Printer PR-90 080||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER PR-90 080</strong></font><br><blockquote>80 columns dot-matrix printer which was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-80</blockquote>

Printer PR-90 600||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER PR-90 600</strong></font><br><blockquote>80-column 9-pin dot matrix printer. A rebadged version of the Seikosha SP-1000 with graphics capabilities</blockquote>
